S2095-4956(24)00061-5 10.1016/j.jechem.2024.01.024 Science Press Fig. 1 Flow diagram of industrial Haber-Bosch process for ammonia manufacturing. Fig. 2 The molecular orbital theory diagram of the N2 molecule, representing its electron sharing pattern within two nitrogen atoms and the energy gap ( Δ E g ) between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), offering high resistance to electron transfer between HOMO and LUMO. Fig. 3 Competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the surface of electrocatalyst suppressing electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) and decreasing the selectivity towards nitrogen molecule which results in low Faradaic efficiency and low ammonia production (a), the hybrid structure of nitrogen molecule with three bond order making the molecule highly inert (b). Fig. 4 The schematic representation of mechanisms of eNRR on electrocatalyst surface (a) dissociative mechanism, (b) associative distal mechanism, (c) associative alternate mechanism and (d) enzymatic mechanism. Fig. 5 Sabatier plot to understand the conditions for the adsorption of the N2 on the catalyst surface (M) so that the interaction should not hinder either product dissociation or limit N2 activation. Fig. 6 The volcano diagrams (represented by lines) combine data for both flat (in black) and stepped (in red) transition metal surfaces in the context of the nitrogen reduction process using a Heyrovsky-type reaction. These diagrams illustrate the results in the absence (solid lines) and presence (dotted lines) of hydrogen bonding effects. The data points on the diagram correspond to the DFT-calculated values of Gibbs free energy ( Δ G ) for specific reaction steps. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [71]. Copyright 2012, Royal Society of Chemistry. Fig. 7 The schematic representation of Mars-van Krevelen mechanism of eNRR on the surface of molybdenum nitride catalyst surface. The reaction cycle starts from the transition metal nitride (TMN) catalyst, undergoing all the elementary reactions, giving two ammonia (NH3) molecules per cycle completion. Fig. 8 Typical density functional theory (DFT) graph for electrochemical nitrogen recduction reaction. The free energy versus reaction co-ordinate graph generated using DFT, in which potential determining step (PDS) corresponds to a maximum uphill energy, identifies the mechanism. The graph will differ from catalyst to catalyst and mechanism to mechanism. Fig. 9 The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction pathway facilitated by lithium (Li). Lithium aids in N2 reduction and its subsequent recycling within the process. Initially, Li+ ions undergo electroplating on the electrode at a suitable potential, leading to reactions with N2 gas, resulting in the formation of Li3N. This compound further converts to NH3 and Li-ion by reacting with protons (H+). Each distinct element/compound is visually represented in the figure. Graphical abstract This review provides a thorough introduction to the necessity of electrochemical synthesis for green ammonia production. Subsequently, it explores the various mechanisms underlying the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction. The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) holds significant promise as a sustainable alternative to the conventional large-scale Haber Bosch process, offering a carbon footprint-free approach for ammonia synthesis. While the process is thermodynamically feasible at ambient temperature and pressure, challenges such as the competing hydrogen evolution reaction, low nitrogen solubility in electrolytes, and the activation of inert dinitrogen (N2) gas adversely affect the performance of ammonia production. These hurdles result in low Faradaic efficiency and low ammonia production rate, which pose obstacles to the commercialisation of the process. Researchers have been actively designing and proposing various electrocatalysts to address these issues, but challenges still need to be resolved. A key strategy in electrocatalyst design lies in understanding the underlying mechanisms that govern the success or failure of the electrocatalyst in driving the electrochemical reaction. Through mechanistic studies, we gain valuable insights into the factors affecting the reaction, enabling us to propose optimised designs to overcome the barriers. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the various mechanisms involved in eNRR on the electrocatalyst surface. It delves into the various mechanisms such as dissociative, associative, Mars-van Krevelen, lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction and surface hydrogenation mechanisms of nitrogen reduction. By unravelling the intricacies of eNRR mechanisms and exploring promising avenues, we can pave the way for more efficient and commercially viable ammonia synthesis through this sustainable electrochemical process by designing an efficient electrocatalyst. Keywords Green ammonia synthesis Electrolysis Electrocatalysis Nitrogen reduction reaction Electrochemical reaction pathways Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction Energy is pivotal in both human existence and the societal framework we inhabit. The energy sector stands as a linchpin in the advancement of a nation’s economy, enhancing living standards and bolstering agriculture, healthcare, education and industries. For the welfare and advancement of individuals, communities, and nations, it is imperative to provide for the energy needs of the present and the future sustainably and economically. Traditional fossil fuels such as coal and oil have been utilised by humankind for energy generation. However, the dependence on conventional resources for energy has inadvertently led to the emission of greenhouse gases, which pollute the air and contribute to the detriment of the environment. Moreover, the limited availability of these natural resources necessitates a shift towards a sustainable energy alternative, which could overcome the above-mentioned concerns. In this context, hydrogen has garnered significant attention as a promising source of fuel owing to its versatility, high energy density (i.e., 9.1 MJ/L at cryogenic temperatures [1]), and its environmentally friendly byproduct, i.e., water vapour when H2 is utilised for combustion or power generation. However, the difficulty lies in storing and transporting H2 because of its inherent high flammability, necessitating innovative solutions to ensure safety and viability. Among various methods available for green hydrogen production, the straightforward approach of water electrolysis stands out as a promising method for generating H2 with high purity. However, a significant challenge arises from reliance on expensive platinum (Pt), the most efficient electrocatalyst [2]. Unfortunately, the commercialisation of this method is impeded by the considerable overpotential due to the sluggish kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction [3]. Considering these aspects of energy storage, transportation and utilisation, ammonia (NH3) emerges as a compelling and practical alternative to hydrogen. Primarily due to the higher energy density and the advantage of utilising existing infrastructure, the widespread applications of NH3 across industries like fertilisers, food production, textiles, pharmaceuticals, and explosives underscores its significance as a crucial chemical feedstock [4]. Beyond its established applications in chemical sectors, NH3 holds promise as a versatile, long-term energy carrier and carbon–neutral fuel. This potential stems from its adeptness at storing energy, facilitated by its high hydrogen density. Like fossil fuels, NH3 serves as both an energy repository and a fuel, generating energy through forming and breaking chemical bonds. In the case of NH3, the net energy gain results from the breaking of nitrogen–hydrogen (N–H) bonds, which, in combination with O2, yields N2 and H2O. Significantly, this implies that if sustainable energy sources drive the production of green NH3, it can be created environmentally sustainably, utilising air containing approximately 78% nitrogen and water. As a result, the energy sector is progressively captivated by the potential of NH3 as a viable solution for fostering sustainable energy carriers. The Haber-Bosch (H-B) process stands as an indispensable cornerstone in the realm of industrial chemistry, playing a pivotal role in the large-scale production of NH3, which Fritz Haber and Carl Bosch developed in 1909 [5–7]. The H-B process has revolutionised global agriculture and food security by enabling the NH3 production from atmospheric inert N2 and H2 gases through a heterogeneous catalytic reaction involving iron (Fe) based catalysts [8] and molybdenum (Mo) as a catalytic promoter at an elevated temperature ranging from 350 to 500 °C and at 150–200 bar pressure [9] to produce NH3 (refer to Eq. 1). The process has facilitated the production of synthetic fertilisers that fuel modern agriculture, and it has not only significantly boosted crop yields but also contributed to addressing the ever-growing demand for food in the expanding global population. Fig. 1 illustrates the principal unit operations and process conditions of industrial-scale NH3 manufacturing plants through the H-B process. Thermodynamically, the reaction of NH3 production from nitrogen gas is characterised as an exothermic reaction with the standard enthalpy of reaction, Δ r H NH 3 ∘ = − 91.78 kJ/mol (Eq. 1). (1) N 2 + 3 H 2 → 2 NH 3 , Δ f H NH 3 ∘ = - 45.89 kJ / mol Regarding the industrial-scale production of NH3, accelerating manufacturing to fulfil market demands necessitates changing the reaction conditions. Even though this reaction (Eq. 1) is exothermic, the H-B process requires a higher temperature; the logic governing this can be understood by Le Chatelier’s principle, which predicts the effect of changes on the system in chemical equilibrium. According to Le Chatelier’s principle, lower temperatures are preferred for exothermic processes; however, the H-B process does not operate under low-temperature conditions due to the linear relationship between temperature and NH3 production rate. The reaction is conducted at elevated temperatures, albeit with a trade-off of reduced reactant conversion. Applying high-pressure conditions shifts the equilibrium towards the product side, enhancing reactant conversion for each pass through the catalyst bed. The H-B process employs a single-pass reactor typically with 2–4 catalyst beds configurations, with each bed capable of 7%–8% reactant conversion per pass [10]. Despite this, only a mere 15%–20% of the reactants are transformed into products with each pass [11]. Therefore, to enhance efficiency, the unreacted gases are separated and recycled, and 97% conversion is achieved [12] to increase overall process effectiveness (refer to Fig. 1). As shown in Fig. 1, elevated temperature is required to enhance the kinetics of this reaction. However, employing elevated temperature conditions results in the breakdown of NH3 into N2 and H2 gases, necessitating subsequent high-pressure conditions. Accounting for the energy needed to utilise high-purity N2 and H2 gases, as well as the processes of mixing, compressing, and condensation, the synthesis of NH3 commonly demands an energy input of approximately 485 kJ/mol of N2. Although this energy quotient is undeniably substantial, it underscores the significance of alternative approaches to reduce this pronounced energy requirement. According to the literature, NH3 produced using renewable energy consumes 33–36 GJ per ton of NH3( ∼ 55 MWh/ton of NH3) for low-temperature electrolysis [13]. Whereas only 26–30 GJ per ton of NH3( ∼ 43 MWh per ton of NH3) is required for high-temperature electrolysis [13–15]. Compared to NH3 produced from methane sources, which requires 46–49 GJ per ton of NH3 [16], which is approximately 38% and 69% higher compared to low-temperature and high-temperature electrolysis operations, respectively [17]. Given that NH3 is a carbon-neutral molecule possessing substantial energy density, i.e., liquid NH3 has an energy density of 15.6 MJ/L, surpassing hydrogen’s energy density of 9.1 MJ/L at cryogenic temperatures [1], it is worth noting that NH3 contains 17.7% hydrogen by weight [18]. With NH3 emerging as a potent fuel source, its future demand is poised to surge. However, meeting this escalating demand would necessitate an increase in production. While the H-B process is the foremost industrial method, its adverse repercussions undermine its productivity. The process relies heavily on H2 gas derived mainly from steam reforming of natural gas, a method notorious for yielding substantial amounts of CO and CO2 gases while demanding a significant energy input. For producing one ton of NH3 using H2 from the steam reforming of natural gas or coal, approximately 1.87 tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) is generated [19]. The NH3 industry operates on a large scale and contributes substantially to greenhouse gas emissions [20]. The H-B process is highly energy-intensive, constituting almost 1% of the world’s yearly natural gas consumption. Additionally, it contributes to approximately 1% to 3% of the overall global energy consumption [18,21–23]. Moreover, 90% of the NH3 produced globally originates from the conventional H-B process [24]. Further, the viability of constructing infrastructure for NH3 production plants is mainly linked to operating on a larger scale. It is worth highlighting that approximately 50% of the production costs are directly linked to procuring natural gas feedstock for the production of H2 gas [12]. The setup of a manufacturing facility demands a substantial initial investment. Additionally, effectively distributing substantial amounts of centrally manufactured fertiliser presents considerable challenges, particularly within developing nations. In order to address the drawbacks associated with the traditional H-B process, researchers are exploring an alternative pathway for NH3 synthesis, such as an electrochemical route. This alternative method involves the synthesis of NH3 in an electrochemical cell by utilising inert N2 gas and a source of protons. The N2 gas reduced at the cathode in an electrochemical cell reacts with the protons present in the electrolyte to produce NH3. Notably, this electrochemical approach allows for NH3 production under mild conditions. However, this process faces several challenges, including concerns associated with energy efficiency, Faradaic efficiency (FE), and the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) when conducted in an aqueous medium [25]. Additional challenges encompass the low conversion of dinitrogen, a limited rate of NH3 production, identifying an optimal electrocatalyst, and catalytic stability and durability. Various electrocatalysts are currently being designed, synthesised, and researched to optimise the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) in response to these challenges. To achieve the desired outcomes, it is essential to not only optimise the design of electrocatalysts and the selection of appropriate electrolytes but also to carefully consider how the electrocatalysis of eNRR occurs under distinct process conditions. In this context, the electrocatalyst plays a significant role in designing an efficient eNRR process. Every electrochemical reaction has a distinct mechanism undergoing which the product is formed. The mechanism of a chemical reaction depicts all the elementary reactions that constitute the process. Mechanism outlines the sequence in which bonds are broken, the sequential steps involved, and the respective rates of these steps. The arrangement of atoms, including those in solvent molecules and the energy levels throughout the process, are defined in a mechanism that helps predict the results. Molecular mechanisms serve as a road map for understanding how reactions proceed at the molecular level. Understanding the mechanism helps researchers to optimise reaction conditions, design better catalysts, control reaction outcomes, and develop more efficient and sustainable synthetic processes. The development of a catalyst for eNRR has been the focus of numerous research papers, which also attempt to explain various mechanisms of eNRR. While concentrating on catalyst design, synthesis, performance and characterisation, limited information is provided about the eNRR mechanism [26,27]. In recent research publications, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been coupled with the eNRR study to identify the mechanism. However, the information on the parameters which are identifying the mechanism by studying free energy versus reaction co-ordinate graph is lean [28–30]. Minimal information is provided about why the catalyst follows a particular mechanism [31]. Answering the expressed factors will help identify the mechanism and justify the catalysts ability to reduce nitrogen. Considering these facts, this review endeavours to provide an in-depth and comprehensive analysis of the diverse eNRR mechanisms documented in the literature. These mechanisms elucidate the pathways through which dinitrogen is transformed into NH3 on the surface of electrocatalysts. Additionally, the significance of using sophisticated tools such as DFT analysis to identify the most efficient mechanism for a given catalyst is discussed. By undertaking this comprehensive assessment of eNRR mechanisms, our review aims to illuminate the intricate nuances inherent to these processes. In doing so, it aims to substantially contribute to developing strategies for highly efficient NH3 synthesis via the electrochemical route. 2 Nitrogen fixation for ammonia synthesis Nitrogen fixation pertains to the transformation wherein atmospheric diatomic nitrogen undergoes conversion into NH3 or alternative nitrogenous compounds such as nitrites and nitrates capable of serving plants and other organisms. NH3 stands as an essential nitrogen source for promoting plant growth, which constitutes a primary component in the formulation of fertilisers. Various methods for the reduction or fixation of N2 are exemplified, including biological nitrogen fixation, photocatalytic routes, and electrocatalytic pathways. The process of N2 fixation is prominently observed in plants through the mechanism of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF). The historical milestones in this context include Boussingault’s investigation in 1838, wherein leguminous crops demonstrated N2 fixation, and subsequently, in 1886, Hellriegel and Wilfarth supplemented concrete evidence regarding the participation of microorganisms in N2 fixation within leguminous plants [21]. The nitrogenase enzyme facilitates the natural N2 fixation process to convert inert nitrogen molecules into NH3 at ambient conditions. The FeMo metalloprotein is the primary cofactor of this nitrogenase enzyme; however, its two metalloproteins are highly susceptible to degradation upon exposure to ambient oxygen. The catalytic prowess of nitrogenase comes into play by breaking the covalent bonds within the inert dinitrogen atom, a feat that entails the addition of three H+ ions per nitrogen atom. This intricate process produces NH3, a crucial nutrient that fulfils the nutritional demands of plants. The nitrogenase enzyme responsible for the BNF is exclusively found within the domain of prokaryotic organisms. The N2 gas forms a binding complex with the MoFe protein component of the nitrogenase enzyme, and the activation of the Fe protein facilitated by magnesium adenosine triphosphate (MgATP) instigates the provision of electrons. This intricate enzymatic process necessitates the utilisation of 16 mol of MgATP, corresponding to an energetic input of 488 kJ/mol [26] and 8 electrons, to reduce one mole of dinitrogen [32]. These electrons are sourced from either flavodoxin or ferredoxin. Emanating from the N2-to-NH3 conversion process is the production of hydrogen gas as a side product [33]. The process of biological NH3 production through dinitrogen reduction by nitrogenase is represented below in Eq. 2 [34]. (2) N 2 + 8 H + + 16 MgATP + 8 e - → 2 NH 3 + H 2 + 16 MgADP + 16 P i From the above reaction (Eq. 2), the production of one molecule of NH3 necessitates the utilisation of 8 molecules of MgATP, which is equivalent to an energy content of 244 kJ/mol, making this BNF process more efficient compared to the H-B process [35]. In nature, various types of nitrogenase have been identified, namely FeMo nitrogenase, FeV nitrogenase, and only Fe nitrogenase; but FeMo nitrogenase has been extensively used for NH3-related studies. On the contrary, using FeV and only Fe nitrogenases produces more dihydrogen during the reaction, thereby reducing both selectivity and efficiency [22]. The stoichiometric equation presented in Eq. (2) has been given at an N2 gas partial pressure of 50.66 bar. However, at 1.13 bar pressure, the evolution of dihydrogen has been reported to have increased significantly. To counter the same, a higher amount of ATP is required to produce the same amount of NH3 [36–38] which results in a higher energy requirement. In addition to the BNF process, the synthesis of NH3 can also be achieved via the photocatalytic reduction of N2. In a photocatalytic method, the photons are supplied to facilitate the reduction of N2. However, it is essential to note that the efficiency of photocatalytic reduction of N2 to NH3 is comparatively lower when contrasted with electrochemical or electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction. This discrepancy arises because not all supplied photons are effectively utilised within the reduction process. Therefore, the electrocatalytic approach to N2 reduction emerges as a highly promising avenue [39], offering the potential for a green and zero-carbon process by utilising electricity generated from renewable sources. The concept of eNRR is not a recent notion, and several studies have explored the production of NH3 through electrochemical routes, contributing to its evolution over time. Tracing back the origins of the electrochemical approach to NH3 synthesis, one can pinpoint its inception to 1998, with the accomplishment of electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis using a solid electrolyte at elevated temperatures [40]. After this study, diverse methodologies for NH3 production have been pursued globally [41]. A comprehensive understanding of the diverse approaches employed by different scientists and the historical progression of the eNRR process can be seen in Table 1 . In 1998, Marnellous and Stoukides [40] reported their research on electrochemical NH3 synthesis. This innovative approach involved the production of NH3 within a solid-state proton-conducting cell reactor operating at an elevated temperature of 570 ° C, utilising H2 and N2 gases. Following their pioneering work, several researchers tried to adapt the process to ambient conditions by exploring various electrocatalysts and electrolytes. In subsequent experimental efforts, a progressive decrease in operating temperature has been observed, as presented in Table 1. Using electrocatalysts spanning metal-free, noble metal, and non-noble metal types for NH3 production under ambient conditions has provided a wider perspective of electrocatalyst possibilities. Additionally, integrating the water-splitting reaction with eNRR is regarded as a promising avenue for advancing toward a more sustainable environment, as shown in Table 1. From a thermodynamic perspective, eNRR demonstrates feasibility with standard Gibbs free energy of formation at 25 °C, Δ f G ° = −16.5 kJ/mol and Δ f H NH 3 ∘ = −45.89 kJ/mol as an exothermic process. The water oxidation coupled eNRR cell has a positive Δ G ° cell value, elucidating that the process of electrochemical ammonia synthesis is non-spontaneous under standard conditions. The broader implementation of this process faces hindrances such as its low yield [42], high electrolyte costs [43], and electrocatalyst quality concerns. Complicating the process further, the N2 molecule exhibits low proton affinity [44] and electron affinity, imposing limitations on the elementary proton-electron transfer steps and thereby complicating the N2 reduction reaction. As previously discussed, the BNF provided an initial perspective on the feasibility of conversion of dinitrogen to NH3 under mild conditions. The thermodynamic calculations have supported the attainability of N2 reduction under ambient conditions through electrolysis. However, a thorough examination of eNRR reveals that despite the uniform product formation, the specific path taken by the reaction significantly diverges based on the substrate or electrocatalyst employed for the eNRR. In the realm of electrochemical reactions, each reaction follows a distinctive mechanism, delineating the sequence of elementary reactions that unfold step by step to yield the overall electrochemical transformation and alterations [45]. Exploring the mechanism offers a more comprehensive comprehension of the processes entailed in eNRR. Examining the reaction mechanism, one can ascertain the reaction’s order, molecularity, rate, and rate constant. The empirical data and outcomes necessitate meticulous scrutiny concerning the reliability of the proposed mechanism. Exploring the mechanism gives information about intermediates formed in each elementary reaction, which helps evaluate these intermediates’ interaction with electrocatalysts. These data will help design optimum electrocatalysts and electrolytes and influence operating conditions. The validation of a proposed mechanism demands meticulously accurate and exhaustive experimentation to assert unequivocally that the observed kinetics align exclusively with the proposed mechanism [46]. The electrochemical reaction representing the eNRR is expressed as shown in Eq. (3) along with a water oxidation reaction at the anode (Eq. 4) [47]. (3) Cathode : N 2 + 6 H + + 6 e - → 2 NH 3 , E N 2 / NH 3 0 = 0.057 V vs . SHE (4) Anode : 3 H 2 O → 6 H + + 3 / 2 O 2 + 6 e - , E H 2 O / O 2 0 = 1 . 229 V vs . SHE The cell potential for the overall cell reaction, i.e., N2 + 3H2O →2NH3 + 3/2O2 is E cell ∘ = −1.172 V vs. SHE. The value of standard Gibbs free energy ( Δ G cell ∘ ) for this overall cell reaction can be calculated using (5) Δ G cell ∘ = - nFE cell ∘ where n is the number of electrons involved in the reaction (6), F is the Faraday’s constant (96,485 C/mol), and E cell ∘ is the cell potential (−1.172 V vs. SHE). The value of Δ G cell ∘ is found to be 678.48 kJ/mol. In the same way, any other anodic reaction can be coupled, and cell potential can be calculated. The individual electrochemical reaction consists of elementary reactions primarily influenced by the type of electrocatalyst, electrolyte, and reaction conditions. Eq. (3) can proceed through the various mechanisms depending on distinct protonation or hydrogenation patterns, which influence intermediates formed during the reaction. The detailed exploration of these mechanisms is imperative for designing the most efficient eNRR electrocatalysts. Recent studies on eNRR integrated the DFT calculations; DFT is found to be a potent technique for elucidating the reaction pathways and predicting the intermediates that entertain the eNRR [48–51]. Further, the DFT is a valuable tool for scrutinising the thermodynamic energy profiles of suggested electrochemical reactions, assessing their viability across various stages, encompassing adsorption, elementary steps including charge transfer reaction, desorption of products and chemical transformation, if any. The DFT calculations can enlighten the reasons behind the activity or inactivity of a specific electrocatalyst for the specific mechanism [52]. Thus, the diverse electrocatalysts being recommended for eNRR often arise as outcomes of DFT calculations [52]. Notably, the DFT also assists in predicting the specific pathway that eNRR follows. In this context, the discussion on DFT and its application in predicting the mechanism is discussed in the subsequent sections. 3 Why eNRR is challenging? While the eNRR route holds certain advantages over the H-B process towards NH3 production, it is accompanied by several obstacles that must be addressed to achieve high efficiency and scalability. To comprehend the precise reasons underlying the challenges of eNRR, an exploration of the properties of the dinitrogen molecule is also essential. The nitrogen molecule possesses a bond order of three, signifying a triple-bonded molecular structure (:N ≡ N:), rendering it one of the most unreactive molecules, and this molecule exhibits sp hybridisation [53]. Consequently, breaking this bond demands a substantial amount of energy, i.e., bond dissociation energy of 225 kcal (948 kJ/mol) or 24.3 eV [54]. The N2 molecules pronounced inertness is a result of its high ionisation potential of 15 eV, a substantial energy demand of 410 kJ/mol for the dissociation of the first covalent bond, and a 10.82 eV energy gap between its highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), collectively resisting for electron transfer [55]. Fig. 2 illustrates the molecular orbital theory structure of the N2 molecule that assists in realising the energy gap. N2 molecules have non-polarity (indicating the absence of a permanent dipole) along with a substantial triplet state energy of 6.17 eV. N2 also exhibits a negative electron affinity of −1.9 eV, a low proton affinity at 5.12 eV, and a significantly high ionisation potential of 15.85 eV [11]. A new method of N2 activation was reported by Chen et al. [56], in which the frustrated Lewis pair catalyst with transition metal and boron co-doped black phosphorus was used for stabilising N2H∗ intermediate. However, this study is only theoretical, but further studies on novel techniques could potentially ease the current hindrances associated with N2 activation. The limited solubility of N2 in water, specifically 0.7 mM aqueous media at 293.15 K, contributes to the sluggish nature of eNRR. The HER consistently competes with eNRR during electrolysis, favouring the reduction of H+ over N2, mainly due to the similar potential values at which both eNRR (Eq. 6) and HER (Eq. 7) occur. The H+ competes with N2 not only for active sites but also for electrons towards the reduction reaction [57], which leads to a decrease in the production rate and FE of eNRR. General strategies for reducing HER include using electrodes with high overpotential towards HER, developing highly N2 selective catalysts, proper electrolyte selection, and optimum operating potential. The use of amphiphilic ionic liquids during catalyst ink preparation inhibits the HER by acting as a proton barrier by forming an N–H bond. Also, it increases the dispersion of the catalyst in the catalyst ink [58]. The H+, which adsorbs onto the active surface, gets reduced to H2 on the initial catalytic surface, which is a swift reaction compared to eNRR (eNRR needs 6 electrons whereas HER needs only 2 electrons), leading to a decrease in FE and yield. The source of H+ in eNRR could be an electrolyte or oxidation reaction at the counter electrode. Based on the counter-reaction, the cell potential is determined; for example, if we consider Eq. (6) and Eq. (8) to be a redox couple, the cell potential will be E ° cell = −1.172 V vs. SHE. Similarly, if Eq. (6) and Eq. (9) are considered as redox couple, the cell potential will be E ° cell = 0.057 V vs. SHE. Any counter reaction that could provide H+ for the reaction can be considered for the redox couple according to the specific reaction conditions. It is not necessary for the water oxidation (Eq. 8) or H2 oxidation (Eq. 9) to be the anodic reaction. It is worth mentioning here that the NH3 synthesis process can be considered sustainable if eNRR is coupled with either Eq. (8) and Eq. (9). In the case of electrolyte being an H+ donor, some intricacies could inhibit the eNRR by increased competition, which is discussed in the next Section 4. The FE for eNRR is calculated using FE = 3cFV/17Q; where c represents the concentration of NH3 formed (M), F is Faraday’s constant (96,485 C/mol), V is the volume of electrolyte (catholyte) (L), Q represents the total charge consumed by electrodes (C). From the above formula, it is imperative that the concentration of NH3 formed directly impacts the FE. The unwanted HER also has a significant effect on lowering FE. The direct consumption of electrons by H+ produces H2 gas, which accounts for the increased current consumed by electrodes that lower the FE of NH3. The higher the competition by the HER, the lower the eNRR efficiency; along with this, the obstacles for eNRR limit the N2 reduction, lowering the efficiency of the process. (6) N 2 + 6 H + + 6 e - → 2 NH 3 , E N 2 / NH 3 0 = 0.057 V vs . SHE (7) 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 , E H + / H 2 0 = 0.000 V vs . SHE (8) 2 H 2 O → 4 H + + O 2 + 4 e - , E H 2 O / O 2 0 = 1.229 V vs . SHE (9) H 2 → 2 H + + 2 e - , E H + / H 2 0 = 0.000 V vs . SHE The eNRR involves complex reactions with multiple successive proton-electron transfer steps compared to HER, which is reported to be a relatively simple and swift reaction. Moreover, a notable aspect is that the majority of electrocatalysts exhibit an inherent inclination towards adsorbing H+ ions as opposed to N2, as depicted in Fig. 3 (a), leading to a negative impact on the selectivity of N2. Despite the comparable thermodynamic reduction potentials of eNRR and HER, the reduction of N2 demands a higher potential due to its inert characteristics. These factors collectively favour HER, contributing to the relatively sluggish nature of eNRR [59]. To circumvent the impact of HER, possible strategies encompass the utilisation of electrodes such as Au and graphite, known for their high overpotential towards HER, adoption of a non-aqueous system, or the development of an electrocatalyst that specifically favours N2 adsorption, thereby facilitating the eNRR. In the pursuit of developing an efficient electrocatalyst, the system design for eNRR is highly anticipated to understand the mechanism of N2 reduction, aimed at comprehending the intricacies of eNRR mechanisms and the prerequisites of each elementary step to yield positive outcomes. In addition to the properties mentioned here, validating the production of NH3 through nitrogen reduction remains challenging, even when experiments are conducted under carefully controlled laboratory conditions. 4 Mechanisms of electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) As mentioned in the earlier section, the feasibility of eNRR continues to be evident through the natural BNF performed by nitrogenase enzymes at ambient conditions. Nevertheless, due to the intricate behaviour of the eNRR, a comprehensive grasp of the underlying mechanisms is essential to facilitate the development of a practical artificial process operating under comparably mild conditions. To attain this goal, in-depth knowledge of the reaction mechanism is paramount. Such understanding not only aids in fine-tuning the reaction to reduce energy barriers but also achieves higher yield and suppresses undesired side reactions. In the pursuit of synthesising value-added chemicals using readily available abundant resources at minimal energy expenses without endangering our environment, controlled changes are desired [60]. Thus, it is necessary to study its mechanisms first to achieve the goal of producing NH3 via the electrochemical route while successfully addressing the challenges mentioned in previous sections. In the past decade, several studies have surfaced intending to unveil the mechanism behind eNRR. These studies employed in situ spectroscopic characterisations that include techniques such as IR spectroscopy coupled with attenuated total reflection, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry; further, these characterisations are complemented by theoretical modelling approaches rooted through DFT. The eNRR mechanism of NH3 production on the surface of heterogeneous electrocatalysts involves the following subsequent steps [61]: 1. Diffusion of N2 from the bulk phase of electrolyte to the interface between electrocatalyst and electrolyte 2. Adsorption of N2 onto the surface of the electrocatalyst 3. Activation of N2, facilitated by the electrocatalyst, coupled with concurrent protonation to yield NH3 4. Desorption of produced NH3 molecule from the electrocatalyst surface 5. Diffusion of NH3 into the electrolyte Typically, these are common steps in heterogeneous electrocatalyst-mediated NRR. Limitations in any of these steps could lead to failure of the eNRR, i.e., the process could be diffusion-limited, adsorption/desorption-limited, or reaction-limited. Let us consider each step in the catalysis of eNRR to realise the challenges. As discussed, the barriers of N2 activation and competing reaction make the eNRR process inefficient. Several strategies are under research and development to overcome the challenges. One of the main concerns of eNRR is the low adsorption and solubility of N2 gas in electrolytes. The dissolved N2 in the electrolyte adsorbs onto the electron deficit active sites of the catalysts. The strategies like phase engineering, defect engineering, heteroatom doping, and interface engineering are utilised for the synthesis of the catalysts to enhance catalyst's ability for the adsorption and selective reduction of N2 [62], along with these defect engineering techniques some surface morphology manipulation techniques are used for the synthesis of N2 selective catalysts [63]. Further, the performance of a particular electrocatalyst can be changed by modifications in the microlevel of original catalysts like size variation, change in orientation and co-ordination, etc. [64]. The transition metal nitride catalysts are one of the most suitable catalysts for NRR due to catalysts’ intrinsic ability towards selective adsorption of N2 molecules. The solubility of N2 is highly limited in the electrolytes; hence, the selection of electrolytes also plays a crucial role in eNRR. Solubility-related hindrances can be tackled using electrolytes with high N2 solubility and optimum operating conditions. Electrolytes can be classified as acidic, basic, and neutral depending on their pH value. Even though the eNRR is feasible in acidic electrolytes, the readily available H+ ions in the medium make the N2 reduction sluggish and even inhibit due to the domination of competing HER. The basic electrolytes are reported to be the most widely utilised electrolytes in studies related to eNRR. Even though it is rich in OH− ions, alkaline electrolytes provide sufficient H+ ions for the eNRR. The electrolyte’s nature and pH are some factors that determine the migration/diffusion of protons and nitrogen in the electrolyte toward active sites of the electrolyte [65]. Aqueous electrolytes are most widely studied due to their low cost, availability, and low maintenance, but HER can be a problem based on operating pH and potential. The solubility of N2 gas at 1 bar pressure and 20 ° C is 20 mg/L (0.7 mM). According to Henry’s law, the solubility of gases has a linear relationship with pressure over a pressure range [66], and solubility decreases with an increase in temperature; on the other hand, the rate of chemical reaction increases with the temperature rise; hence reaction should be conducted at the optimum temperature and pressure combination to get the better yield. Continuous gas purging operations are an option when the solubility of N2 gas is minimal, ensuring that the reaction is not limited by reactant availability. Some non-aqueous electrolytes show better N2 solubility of 4–5 mM; using non-aqueous electrolytes will help with competing HER due to the lack of free H+ ions in the electrolyte, which means the electrolyte itself is not a source of H+. The H+ for the reaction must be supplied by the counter or oxidation reaction occurring at the anode. This proton is transferred between anode and cathode using ethanol, proton exchange membranes (PEM), ionic liquids such as 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate and 1-butyl-3- methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide. A recent review article by Ham et al. concluded that membranes incorporating imidazolium ions in ionic liquids exhibit enhanced conductivity and diffusion coefficients for H+ [58]. One of the strategies for suppressing HER includes surface hydrophobic coating/modification of catalysts. The hydrophobic coating proposes advantages like increased surface area with exposed active catalyst sites, increased N2 concentration near the catalyst, better N2 and electrocatalyst interaction [67]. Sim et al. [68] experimented with a zeolitic-imidazole framework (ZIF) as a hydrophobic coating over a Pt/Au catalyst. They observed a 44 times higher FE when using hydrophobic coating over the catalyst than the non–hydrophobic coated catalyst. The hydrophobic layer acts as a barrier and weakens the H+ adsorption by modifying the d-band of the catalyst. Wang et al. [69] conducted a similar experiment of surface hydrophobic modification of MXene (Ti3C2Ti x ) catalyst and observed the increase in both FE and NH3 formation rate, and concluded that the hydrophobic layer inhibits the entry of water molecules, consequently inhibiting HER. The surface hydrophobic modification makes the catalyst aerophilic and hydrophobic, which provides optimum contact between electrolyte, catalyst, and N2, and helps overcome mass transfer limitations due to the low solubility of N2 in most electrolytes to achieve higher FE and NH3 yield [70]. The operating potential window is higher in non-aqueous electrolytes than in aqueous electrolytes due to the limited availability of H+ ions in the system. Along with this, ionic liquids, in comparison to traditional molecular solvents, exhibit favourable attributes such as high electrical conductivity, robust electrostatic fields, distinctive microenvironments, and the presence of numerous weak interactions. These qualities contribute significantly to the effective mitigation of the HER and enhancement of eNRR efficiency [64]. Furthermore, eNRR can be inhibited by the deposition of NH3 on the catalyst surface, reducing the density of active sites. Strong interaction between product and catalyst could lead to this phenomenon. The electrolyte should also have high solubility for NH3 so that all the molecules are dissolved in the electrolyte, helping in accurately quantifying NH3 formed. Considering all these factors related to catalyst design, electrolyte selection, and operational conditions, the optimum combination of these three will help to avoid HER and consequently improve the FE of the eNRR process. The next step is the adsorption of the N2 molecule on the catalyst surface. This adsorption of nitrogen molecules can be side-on adsorption or end-on adsorption; depending on the adsorption patterns, the mechanism is classified. The adsorption pattern of the molecule depends on the adsorption energy. When the molecule gets adsorbed to the catalyst, the bond length of the N2 molecule deviates, facilitating the protonation of the N2 molecule. If the adsorption is very strong, subsequent reactions are resisted to electron conductivity, leading to the failure of the catalyst. This is one of the important considerations while designing the catalyst. In the same context, it is crucial for the catalyst’s adsorption energy to favourably promote the adsorption of N2 over the adsorption of H+. This preference ensures that the catalyst exhibits selectivity towards eNRR rather than the competing HER [57]. Next comes reactions of eNRR, depending on how the reduction reaction takes place on the surface of the electrocatalyst, i.e., the different hydrogenation sequences and breaking of three covalent bonds within the N2 molecule; the process of electrocatalysis is further categorised generally as a dissociative mechanism and an associative mechanism. In this context, the free energies of intermediates of eNRR were calculated by Skúlason et al. [71] by employing the DFT, and it confirmed the interdependence of multiple reaction steps in eNRR, highlighting that these steps are interconnected rather than independent. Furthermore, there exists a linear correlation among the different intermediate stages, enabling a single descriptor of the N☆ binding energy (here ☆ denotes that the atom is affiliated with the active site of the electrocatalyst, and this notation applies throughout the entire article) to demonstrate the electrocatalytic activity [72]. The binding energy relationship of NH x ☆ and N 2 H x ☆ scale linearly with N☆ binding energy. By establishing the relation between NH x ☆ and N ☆ or N 2 H x ☆ and N ☆ species, which help in identifying the necessary over-potentials for various metals that involve distinct potential-determining steps, thus promoting the employment of a singular descriptor. This becomes especially pertinent when addressing the high binding energies of N ☆ species [22]. Transition metals are widely employed to electrocatalyse the activation of N ≡ N through electron acceptance and back-donation. This process forms the foundation of the volcano diagram depicting the correlation between overpotential and N ☆ binding energy for various transition metals. The presentation of this relationship is depicted through a volcano plot, and further discussion on this is provided in Subsection 4.2.3. A lone pair of electrons from N2 are accepted by transition metals, and subsequently, electrons are donated back to nitrogen’s anti-bonding orbital; this process initiates the activation of N ≡ N bond [11]. The eNRR encompasses a series of steps involving the transfer of proton-electron pairs. Thus, the mechanism can be categorised into dissociative and associative pathways based on the order of proton (H+) addition to the N2 molecule and the resulting arrangement of N2 adsorption on the electrocatalyst surface, and a detailed analysis of these pathways is presented in the following Subsections 4.1 and 4.2, respectively. 4.1 Dissociative mechanism Several rates of reaction models grounded on the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism have been proposed in the recent literature on the NH3 synthesis reactions employing Ru-based catalysts [73,74]. Most of these reaction rate equation models have been formulated assuming that the dissociative adsorption of nitrogen is the rate-determining step (RDS); hence, this mechanism is regarded as the dissociative mechanism in the literature [75]. In the dissociative mechanism, the initial step encompasses the cleavage of bonds within the N2 molecule. Notably, this breaking of the N ≡ N bond occurs during adsorption, preceding any protonation steps [55]. This leads to the formation of two distinct N atoms, which are separated by a distinct distance; the hydrogenation/protonation proceeds after cleavage. Two separated nitrogen atoms undergo hydrogenation independently, giving NH3 [76]. All the elementary reactions of the dissociative mechanism are represented in Table 2 . The industrial H-B process follows the dissociative mechanism [77]. The first hydrogen addition to the nitrogen molecule requires high energy; therefore, harsh conditions like high temperature (350–500 ° C) and pressure (150–200 bar) are necessary for the process, which leads to a dissociative pathway into a high energy requirement mechanism. However, the dissociative pathway is less favourable for N2 to NH3 conversion electrocatalytically [26] compared to other parallel mechanisms. The dissociative mechanism is favoured on flat electrocatalyst surfaces at high binding energies of N*. The addition of a second proton-coupled electron transfer (H++e − ) from NH* to NH2* on a flat electrocatalytic surface is the potential determining step (refer to Table 2). The dissociative mechanism performs better on the noble metal electrocatalyst. Rh catalyst is most effective for stepped surfaces with an intermediate value of N ∗ binding energy; the dissociative mechanism is suitable. The final proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) and the NH3 desorption are potential determining steps on the stepped catalyst surface. The dissociative mechanism on flat surfaces is dominant at slightly lower binding energies of N*, and the dissociation of dinitrogen becomes a potential determining step [22,71]. Refer to Fig. 4 (a) to follow the dissociative mechanism on the catalyst surface. Iridium has better catalytic nitrogen reduction ability in dissociative mechanism than platinum on flat catalyst surfaces [78]. Even though the employment of noble metals could benefit a dissociative mechanism, their high cost hinders their usage in large-scale applications [79]. 4.2 Associative mechanism Unlike in the dissociative mechanism, the N ≡ N bonds are not broken on adsorption in the associative mechanism; the bonds break during the hydrogenation process. In the associative pathway, the nitrogen molecule, dissolved in the electrolyte, gets diffused towards the electrocatalyst from the bulk and is adsorbed on the catalytic surface with end-on mode or side-on mode [22]. The N ≡ N triple bonds are gradually cleaved with simultaneous hydrogenation with the formation of different intermediates, which makes the associative pathway more complex compared to the dissociative pathway. The associative mechanism is also called the Elley-Rideal (E-R) associative mechanism [75]. Based on the hydrogenation sequence of the N2 molecule, the adsorption pattern associative pathway is further classified into distal, alternate, and enzymatic pathways. An associative pathway has been reported to be followed by FeMo nitrogenase by either a distal or alternate mechanism [22]. The eNRR mechanism on Au-thin film electrocatalysts was investigated using the surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS) [80], and results indicated that N ≡ N bond in dinitrogen molecule broken simultaneously with the addition of hydrogen and electron addition; hence authors proposed that the eNRR on Au-based electrocatalysts follows the associative mechanism. 4.2.1 Distal pathway The distal pathway was first proposed by Schrock [81], where he proposed the mechanism of nitrogen reduction on the surface of [(HIPTNCH2CH2)3N]Mo catalyst with Mo centre. The structure and reaction mechanism of the same can be found in Ref. [81]. In the distal pathway, the nitrogen molecule is adsorbed onto the active site of the catalyst in end-on mode, in which preferentially, the hydrogenation first takes place on the nitrogen atom away from the surface of the catalyst [82]; this atom can be referred as distal nitrogen atom, transfer of three proton-electron couples gives out first NH3 molecule which gets desorbed from the catalyst surface exposing the other nitrogen atom, i.e., proximal nitrogen atom for subsequent hydrogenation, which forms second NH3 molecule. After both the molecules are desorbed from the active site of the electrocatalyst surface, the catalyst surface is ready for the next cycle of eNRR reaction. The reaction scheme is represented in Table 2. Unlike the dissociative mechanism, the protonation of two nitrogen atoms does not co-occur; instead, it is a subsequent reaction in the distal mechanism. Van et al. [22] conducted a study of electrochemical reduction of N2 on a Ru(0001) surface, considering both dissociative and associative pathways. The potential need for all redox processes to become active on a flat Ru(0001) surface was −1.08 V. In contrast, the adequate potential on a stepped surface was −0.43 V. Because of the lower energy intermediates (*NNH2 and *N + NH3) compared to *NHNH and *NHNH2, the distal pathway is preferred over the alternate method; but for the same Ru stepped surface electrocatalyst in dissociative mechanism, potential determining step (PDS) was found to be −0.16 V, supporting the fact that even though the dissociative mechanism is complicated, using the proper catalyst, i.e., noble metal electrocatalyst could make the process efficient. Less external driving power is needed for the dinitrogen reduction dissociative process on a stepped Ru surface. In Fig. 4(b), the schematic representation of the associative distal mechanism step by step is presented, including each hydrogenation step till the NH3 is desorbed from the electrocatalyst surface. As the nitrogen molecule enters the reaction, the bond length between the two nitrogen atoms increases in each step, which makes the bond weaker, and the further protonation step eventually leads to the breaking of the bond [83]. 4.2.2 Alternate pathway In an alternate pathway, the nitrogen molecule gets chemically adsorbed onto the catalyst’s surface in end-on mode. However, the pathway differs from distal in the sequence of hydrogenation. Unlike in the distal pathway, the hydrogenation in the alternate pathway takes place on both the nitrogen atom alternatively and forms two molecules of NH3 at the last step. The NH3 formed gets desorbed and diffuses into the bulk phase, leaving behind an empty active site [26]. Refer to Fig. 4(c) to follow the alternate mechanism and Table 2 gives the reactions involved in the associative alternate mechanism, where *denotes the active site (nitrogen adsorbed to the active site of the catalyst surface). The associative pathway is widely followed by some noble metal-based catalysts like Au, Ru, Pd based catalysts [55], non-noble metals like molybdenum and copper-based catalysts [84] and metal-free catalysts B, B4C, carbon, graphene, Mxene [21], their derivatives [26]. Song et al. [85] described N,P co-doped porous carbon to follow an alternate associative mechanism to give NH3. In the alternate pathway, the hydrazine byproduct formation is one of the concerns. Hydrazine produced is very less compared to NH3 [86] because the process of hydrazine desorption from the catalyst surface is extremely endothermic [76] and the concentration of hydrazine (N2H4) can be determined by Watt and Crisp method [87] and concentration of hydrazine byproduct has been reported in the eNRR studies. 4.2.3 Enzymatic pathway The enzymatic pathway shares similarities with that of the alternative pathway (in the pattern of hydrogenation) but differs in the adsorption pattern. In the enzymatic pathway, the nitrogen molecule gets adsorbed onto the catalyst’s surface in side-on mode. In the side-on mode of adsorption, the two N atoms, bound to the enzyme’s surface, alternatively get hydrogenated and give two molecules of NH3 [77,82,88]. The side-on adsorption of the nitrogen molecule (*N-N*) on the electrocatalyst was predicted to be stable and facile for reduction. All the elementary reactions involved in the enzymatic mechanism of nitrogen reduction are presented in Table 2, and Fig. 4(d) illustrates the enzymatic mechanism on the catalyst surface. The associative mechanism distributes activation energy to subsequent intermediate reactions, which allows the NRR to proceed at ambient conditions. Since the initial step in all associative mechanisms is the adsorption of nitrogen onto the catalytic surface, a strong enough interaction between the catalyst surface and nitrogen molecule is a prerequisite for the reaction [89]. The heterogeneous catalysis uses a qualitative concept of the Sabatier principle given by French chemist Paul Sabatier, which states that the interaction between catalyst and reactant (in our case, nitrogen) should be just enough so that the interaction should be neither too strong nor too weak. The graphical representation of the statement can be realised in Fig. 5 . Weak interaction will prevent the molecule from binding to the catalyst, leading to a nitrogen activation failure and elevated overpotential [90], and when the interaction is too intense, the product fails to dissociate properly from the electrocatalyst surface, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. This principle can be graphically represented by plotting the rate vs. bond strength graph and it gives a volcano-type relation [91]. The mechanism favoured depends on the catalyst used in the reaction. Norskov and his coworkers generated a volcanic plot by contrasting various metals’ surface characteristics and catalytic qualities, i.e., stepped and flat surfaces. A volcano plot is a graph of the – Δ G value of the PDS versus the nitrogen binding energy (on the corresponding metal surface). Considering the flat catalyst surface at high nitrogen binding energy, the dissociative mechanism dominates; if the binding energy is low/weak, the associative mechanism is preferred. However, in both mechanisms, the addition of the first proton-electron couple to the adsorbed nitrogen species is PDS. Fig. 6 represents the combined volcanic plots for stepped and flat transition metal surfaces [71]. For low binding energy of N* and flat catalytic surface, adding the first proton and electron to free nitrogen is limited in an associative pathway. The addition of dinitrogen and its protonation is more accessible on the surface of the earlier transition metals, and the reduction of *NH to *NH2 and *NH2 to NH3 limits the redox potential. Molybdenum emerges as the most efficient catalyst for this pathway, as it is anticipated to require only a slight negative potential to make all elementary steps feasible. However, on stepped catalyst surfaces, problems arise during the formation and desorption steps of the mechanism. In such cases, ruthenium is the optimal choice catalyst [71]. We can identify the suitable element or their derivatives for the nitrogen activation from the volcano plot, but DFT calculations are necessary to determine the electrocatalyst’s reaction mechanism. 4.3 Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism The MvK mechanism is considered one of the most effective eNRR mechanisms. MvK mechanism explains the interaction of gas molecules on the surface of a catalyst, like adsorption and desorption, which Mars and Van Krevelen introduced in 1954 [92]. This MvK mechanism was initially observed in metal oxide catalysts, where an oxidation reaction was initiated by creating and populating oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [93,94]. In the MvK mechanism, the catalyst surface is active, creating vacancies that are replenished by reactant atoms after the product dissociation from the catalyst surface. Like metal oxides, metal nitrides can be used for nitrogen reduction, which is being studied now for eNRR [95]. Recently, the MvK mechanism was introduced by Abghoui et al. [96] for eNRR, which could be more efficient than associative and dissociative mechanisms. The MvK mechanism on the surface of the molybdenum nitride catalyst surface with all the elementary steps is presented in Fig. 7 . In the MvK mechanism, the lattice N atom on the transitional metal nitride surface is reduced to NH3, and the molecule gets desorbed, creating a nitrogen-vacancy in the lattice. These vacancies shall be fulfilled by nitrogen molecules in order for eNRR to take place continuously. The calculations based on DFT show that the dissociation of nitrogen molecules on the surface of transitional metal nitrides is endothermic; the activation barrier is large, which inhibits the dissociative pathway. The onset potential for the MvK mechanism is less than the associative pathway. This makes the MvK mechanism the most favourable path for eNRR in the presence of transitional metal nitride catalysts [96]. The MvK process includes a stage where the first NH3 molecule is formed without N2 adhering to the electrocatalyst surface. This lowers the energy barrier for NH3 production as it avoids the need for cleavage of the triple bond in N2. Instead, the NH3 molecule is formed from the N site on the nitride electrocatalyst surface. Subsequently, to sustain the cycle, more N2 molecules must replenish the vacancies generated by the desorption of NH3. In this step, the triple bond in N2 molecule needs to be cleaved. The vacant surface of nitride catalysts leads to elevated surface energy, thereby encouraging the adsorption of N2 and enabling the breaking of the N2 triple bond [97]. The reaction pathway of the MvK mechanism can be realised from Table 2. Abghoui and Skúlason [98] studied the activity of different transition metal nitrides (TMNs) towards eNRR using DFT calculations and found almost all the TMNs dominantly showed MvK over associative and dissociative mechanisms based on the favourable onset potential. The catalysts such as VN, ZrN, NbN, and CrN with rock salt structure were found to be more active and selective towards eNRR than the competing HER reaction [99]. Abghoui and Skúlasons DFT calculations on CrN(111) and MnN(111) catalyst towards MvK mechanism, the PDS was determined to be 0.71 and 0.54 eV, respectively at U = 0 V. The simultaneous calculations with U = −0.71 V made all reaction steps for CrN(111) downhill, and U = −0.54 V made all reaction steps for MnN(111) except for RDS. Since RDS does not involve electron–proton exchange, the uphill energy barrier associated with RDS cannot be transcended by external bias [98]. This implies that at the PDS potential, all the elementary reaction steps become energetically favourable in a downhill manner on the free energy versus reaction co-ordinate graph. In addition to the various benefits offered by the MvK mechanism, there are some concerns, the most important of which is identifying RDS. There is no clear trend for NH3 formation on transition metal nitride surface; for all we know, multiple protonation steps could be rate determining or release of NH3 molecule could be RDS [100]; hence, the application of available volcano plots logic for comparing the catalysts becomes insignificant, especially for TMNs as more than one descriptor needed to be considered for finding the RDS including the binding energies of both N* and H* [71]. Failure to identify RDS would hinder the theoretical calculations of reaction kinetics and predict the NH3 formation rate. As discussed, DFT calculations are popular in eNRR catalysis in identifying the mechanism and catalysts’ ability to reduce N2 to NH3. DFT is a widely utilised quantum–mechanical approach in chemistry and physics. Its primary application involves determining the electronic arrangement of atoms, molecules, and solids. Since its inception in the 1970s, DFT has gained immense popularity in computational solid-state physics [101]. DFT-based calculations are essential for understanding the mechanism and determining reaction pathways by Gibbs energy calculations. DFT calculates the free energy change along the reaction co-ordinate by considering the adsorption energy, entropy, zero point energy, energy of the intermediate, operating temperature, operating potential, and pH. The electronic configurations of all the atoms in the catalyst, lattice structure, lattice parameters, crystal defects, and atomic vacancies are also considered in DFT calculation, which accurately calculates the interaction between catalyst and reactants, helps in understanding the effects of different factors such as defect, facet, and functionalisation. Typical DFT graphs have free energy ( Δ G) vs. reaction co-ordinate graph, which is depicted in Fig. 8 . In the DFT plot, the trend of free energy of intermediates, activation energy, and potential barrier corresponding to different steps varies from catalyst to catalyst and mechanism to mechanism. The DFT calculations for eNRR are done, assuming all the possible mechanisms for a particular catalyst. For a particular catalyst, different mechanistic calculations result in a different DFT graph, which includes the intermediates and their free energies. The highest uphill energy step is considered to be PDS for the particular mechanism; the mechanism with the lowest PDS value is reported to be followed by the catalyst to reduce N2. Fig. 8 elucidates the nature of a typical DFT graph. Applying the PDS value as bias potential to the eNRR system makes all the reaction steps downhill in terms of free energy except for RDS as it is not associated with PCET [98]. The potential determining step is found to be the elementary step, which has the highest positive free energy change between consecutive steps (uphill potential). The N2 reduction pathway on the catalyst surface follows the mechanism with the least uphill free energy barrier or least free energy difference in PDS out of all the mechanisms assumed [102]. We have discussed some mechanisms for eNRR, which are confirmed and proposed after DFT calculations. Refer to Fig. 8, where we have tried to generalise the plot of eNRR after referring to different studies related to eNRR. Skúlason et al. [71] studied the catalytic activity of different metal catalysts on stepped and flat surfaces in eNRR. Their experiment showed that the most active elements on the volcanic map were found to be Mo, Fe, Rh and Ru; but the metals were also active for HER, which paved the way for competitive reaction, leading to a reduction in FE. The other finding was that when the bias voltage on a specific metal electrode is between −1.5 and −1.0 V vs. SHE, the flat surfaces of early transition metals such as Sc, Y, Ti, and Zr more strongly bind with nitrogen than with hydrogen atoms, resulting in a higher selectivity and yield [103,104]. The choice of materials in synthesising catalysts significantly influences the FE, selectivity, and mechanism of eNRR. Utilising DFT in investigating these materials provides insights into intermediates, intermolecular interactions, and the RDS, ultimately aiding in informed decision-making for catalyst selection [24]. 4.4 Lithium mediated eNRR pathway Scientists worldwide have suggested various catalysts to enhance the efficiency of eNRR, including metal oxides [105], noble metals [86], metal nitrides [106] and metal sulfides [107]. Although a large variety of catalysts are reported, most of them suffer from low FE (below 10%) and low NH3 production rates (below 10−10 mol/cm2 s) [55,108]. Lithium metal (Li) has a standard electrode potential of −3.05 V vs. SHE, making it a highly reducing agent. This reducing property of Li has been exploited in the eNRR process to reduce N2 to NH3. Among these catalysts, lithium metal demonstrated better FE compared to previously reported methods of eNRR [109–112], which makes it popular among other catalysts or their derivatives. Lazouski et al. [113] attempted a lithium-mediated non-aqueous eNRR approach and reported an FE of 35 ± 6%. Most electrochemical processes include aqueous electrolytes, accounting for low selectivity and NH3 production rate. The non-aqueous lithium-mediated approach could overcome the problems above. The production of NH3 from non-polar gaseous reactants like nitrogen and hydrogen is limited by their low solubility value and slow transport in non-aqueous solvents. Lazouski et al. [114] developed a non-aqueous lithium-mediated approach for electrochemical nitrogen reduction using gas diffusion electrodes, lithium metal, hydrogen gas from water splitting reaction, nitrogen gas, and tetrahydrofuran (THF). The catalyst-coated stainless steel cloths were used as electrodes (platinum coating at the anode and lithium coating at the cathode), and ethanol was used as a proton donor in the experiments done by Lazouskis group [114]. Fig. 9 illustrates the mechanism of lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction. The use of GDE helps in efficient contact between gas, electrolyte, and Li, resulting in better mass transfer among all three phases. The reaction scheme involves three steps; the process initiates with the electrodeposition of Li on the cathode from Li+ ions, which are dissolved in the THF (Eq. 10). Highly reducing Li forms Li3N on interaction with dissolved nitrogen in the medium. This process of formation of Li3N is called lithium nitridation, which is a spontaneous process (Eq. 11). Lithium nitride (Li3N) further reacts with the protons, which are shuttled by C2H5OH between cathode and anode, which results in the formation of NH3 and Li+ ion (Eq. 12). Li+ ion is cycled back, and a continuous process is established. The intricacies arise in calculating accurate overpotential for the process due to the in situ electrodeposition of Li from Li-ion, which accounts for potential loss. A study conducted by the Westheads group introduces a straightforward approach to determining the RHE potential in lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction. The method enables an exploration of the Nernst equation, uncovering the potential losses attributed to Li-ion solvation in the electrolyte and resistive losses arising from solid electrolyte interphase formation [115]. (10) 3 Li + + 3 e - → 3 Li Electrodeposition (11) 3 Li + 1 / 2 N 2 → Li 3 N Lithium nitridation (12) Li 3 N + 3 H + → NH 3 + 3 Li + ( Nitrogen reduction ) Refer Table 2 for a comparison of elementary reactions across various mechanisms. Additionally, Suryanto et al. [116] explored a comparable lithium-mediated eNRR pathway employing a similar mechanism. However, they introduced a novel element to the process by substituting the previously employed ethanol with a phosphonium cation to facilitate proton shuttling. This modification resulted in enhanced ionic conductivity and improved lithium deposition onto the substrate. Using a phosphonium salt as a proton shuttle led to achieving a 69% FE in the lithium-mediated eNRR. The approach adopted in this method mirrors the lithium-mediated reaction mechanism outlined in Table 2. 4.5 Surface hydrogenation eNRR mechanism Ling et al. [117] conducted eNRR studies on noble metal-based catalysts at very low potentials (−0.20 and −0.05 V). The DFT calculations conducted on the surface of a noble metal-based catalyst at very low potentials revealed a deviation from all previously suggested mechanisms. The first step in the previously reported associative and dissociative mechanism was the adsorption of N2 gas on the catalyst surface due to a very weak interaction of the noble metals with N2 at lower potentials (−0.20 to −0.05 V) the reduction of H+ precedes the N2 gas adsorption, which resulted in the identification of new eNRR mechanism. It is described as the surface hydrogenation mechanism. The DFT studies were carried out by Ling’s group on the face-centred cubic (fcc) Au(100), Au(101), Pd(100), and Pd(101) and hexagonal close-packed (hcp) Au(110) and Au(110). The energy requirement for the activation of nitrogen gas via dissociative mechanism was calculated and found to be 5.95, 5.32, 5.13, 5.09, 1.20, and 3.33 eV for hcp Au(110), hcp Au(110), fcc Au(100), fcc Au(101), fcc Pd(100), and fcc Pd(101) surfaces, respectively. This high energy requirement inhibits the dissociative mechanism. Conversely, the associative mechanism is limited by N2 gas activation and hydrogenation due to poor catalyst and N2 gas interaction. To overcome this energy barrier, a high negative potential is required. Hence, at lower potential values, the noble metal-based catalysts were concluded to follow the surface hydrogenation mechanism. First, H+ undergoes reduction instead of N2 adsorption. This H+ reduction leads to hydrogenation of the catalyst surface (surface hydrogenation). The N2 reacts with the hydrogenated surface to produce N2H2; this conversion is justified by the lesser energy requirement than the formation of N2H in associative mechanism, data related to this can be seen in Table 3 . Further, N2H2 reacts with the available proton-electron pair and gets converted to NH3; this last step is spontaneous and exothermic. The reaction scheme for the surface hydrogenation is illustrated in Table 2. In this mechanism, the surface hydrogenation step (the first step) was reported as PDS, and the formation of N2H2 is reported to be RDS because of the high energy requirement for breaking N ≡ N. These steps contribute to the surface hydrogenation mechanism’s low production rate of NH3. The highest NH3 production was recorded by hcp Au, and fcc Pd gives the lowest rate due to their respective energy barrier [117]. The energy corresponding to RDS in the surface hydrogenation mechanism for the reported catalyst is provided in Table 3 [117]. Different electrocatalysts have been developed since the initiation of the idea of eNRR, and the efforts to develop the best catalyst and the process are still in progress. A list of catalysts classified based on their reported mechanism has been compiled in Table 4 . From this table, we can conclude that the mechanism followed by the catalyst does not depend on the element present in it, i.e., the iron-based catalyst can follow myriad mechanisms based on the catalyst’s interaction with the nitrogen atom, adsorption energy, and free energies of intermediates. So, the assumption of the mechanism based on the chemical composition of the catalyst alone is unrealistic and inaccurate. As discussed, the significance of the eNRR in the energy sector has led to the exploration of diverse methods for NH3 production. Santhosh and Sankannavar [41] conducted a comprehensive review on innovative electrochemical approaches for producing NH3 through the reduction of N2. The study evaluates catalytic performance and economic analysis, providing valuable insights for researchers to identify suitable strategies aligned with specific reaction parameters. By addressing the problems limiting the reduction reaction, including catalyst design, gas solubility, and competing HER, the NH3; yield can be increased significantly, which further increases the efficiency of the process. Given the objective of achieving industrial-scale NH3 production, there is a strong demand for studies that delve into the scaling-up aspects of eNRR. The challenges in eNRR are not just limited to the catalyst. The reaction is affected by many factors, including electrolyte design and selection, operating conditions (temperature, pressure, potential), cell design and architecture, and separation of products, which also carry significant importance, if not the same as a catalyst. Recognising the paramount demand of NH3 in industrial applications, a comprehensive approach extends beyond merely developing efficient and selective catalysts. Even though selectivity-related issues are the main obstacles to the scale-up of eNRR, achieving scalability entails addressing diverse factors such as economics, cell design, product separation, and overall architecture [118]. From an economic standpoint, eNRR is more cost-effective than conventional H-B production processes assisted by steam reforming [41], establishing its viability on an industrial scale. In the realm of cell design, researchers experiment with various types of cells, including single chamber cells, H type cell, PEM type cell, RFBs, etc., at the laboratory scale. Challenges at the laboratory scale can often be mitigated through simple modifications, but scaling up introduces bottlenecks. Ensuring that performance and efficiency do not vary significantly when extrapolating the laboratory-scale design to an industrial level is crucial. Factors such as efficient mass transfer within the cell and meticulous design and operating considerations become important during scaling. Given the volatility of NH3, special precautions are imperative during eNRR to ensure that the produced NH3 is either dissolved in the electrolyte or captured in a gaseous phase. Research strategies, such as employing acid traps and airtight containment, aim to maximise NH3 retention in the cell. Separation techniques, contingent on electrolyte characteristics, involve considerations like relative volatility and boiling point difference. Underscoring studies on NH3 separation post eNRR are highly recommended for industrial-scale production. The cell design aspects like continuous and batch operation of the process, designing the electrodes and cell, and mode of stacking of the cell are some of the necessary factors for successful scale-up of eNRR, keeping the process economical in comparison to other pre-existing NH3 production methods. To summarise the eNRR mechanisms, the reduction of N2 on an electrocatalyst surface is mainly attributed to its interaction with the catalyst. Adsorption energy is vital in determining the adsorption mode, i.e., side-on or end-on. As the Sabatier plot represents, the adsorption should not be too strong or too weak; it should be optimum. A strong interaction poisons the catalyst by diminishing the active site; on the contrary, weak catalytic interaction fails to activate N2, but both will contribute towards a decrease in the efficiency of the process. After adsorption, reduction pathways are classified as dissociative and associative. The three intramolecular covalent bonds are broken in the dissociative mechanism as the N2 adsorbs on the catalytic surface, which requires high energy. The dissociative mechanism accounts for the high energy requirement in the industrial H-B process. In associative mechanisms, the adsorption mode is critical in determining the mechanism. If the adsorption of N2 is the end-on mode, the reaction follows either a distal or alternate mechanism. In the distal mechanism, the distal N atom to the electrocatalyst surface gets hydrogenated to NH3, the release of which initiates the hydrogenation of proximal N. In the same way, the end-on mechanism can also lead to an alternate mechanism. In the alternate mechanism, the hydrogenation of both N atoms occurs alternately rather than preferentially (as in the distal mechanism), giving two molecules of NH3. In the case of side-on adsorption, the reaction follows an enzymatic mechanism. The enzymatic mechanism differs from the alternate mechanism in the mode of N2 adsorption; the hydrogenation of N atoms occurs alternatively. The three mechanisms of associative mechanism vary from one another in just one aspect, i.e., either adsorption mode or hydrogenation sequence. Abghoui and Skúlason [103] have proposed applying the MvK mechanism in eNRR. The MvK mechanism was reported to be followed by TMNs. Due to the presence of an N atom in the catalyst, the first NH3 does not need external N2, and due to the catalyst’s innate ability of N2 selectivity, the MvK mechanism gives better eNRR yield and FE. Due to the high reduction potential of Li+, the lithium-mediated pathway has become popular in recent years. The highly reducing Li+ reacts with N2 and forms Li3N, which further reacts with H+ and gives NH3. Because of its high reducing property, lithium-mediated eNRR has high N2 selectivity and FE compared to most reported methods and catalysts. Studies conducted by Ling et al. [117] on noble metal catalysts, when employed for eNRR at low potential values, deviated from previously reported mechanisms which led to the surface hydrogenation mechanism. In the surface hydrogenation mechanism, H+ reduction precedes N2 adsorption, leading to the catalyst surface’s hydrogenation. Dinitrogen reacts with the hydrogenated surface and forms N2H2, which requires less energy than the formation of N2H intermediate, and this step is RDS in the surface hydrogenation mechanism. Further, this N2H2 reacts with protons and electrons to give NH3. An RDS plays an important role in determining the mechanism. RDS is the step in which the highest uphill energy is required to form the corresponding reaction intermediate. First principle calculations via DFT are important in identifying catalysts’ ability towards eNRR and efficiency.
