Understanding the mechanism is crucial to developing a selective catalyst for N2 adsorption and reduction. 5 Future research scope in the eNRR field Ammonia is a highly valued chemical in the agriculture and pharmaceutical industries. The sustainable NH3 synthesis environment is one of the major concerns because of the problems related to the traditional H-B process. In 2014, during the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) held in India, the Global Commission on Adaptation (GCA) emphasised that meeting the food needs for an expanding global population of 10 billion by 2050, will require a 50% boost in crop production [119]. This factor imperatively surges the demand for fertilisers like urea. NH3 is a vital part of the fertiliser industry and it is also emerging as an alternate fuel, reaching the global demand of NH3 production considering the contribution to global warming. The H-B process of NH3 manufacturing is highly unsustainable. The eNRR holds significant potential for addressing global energy, agriculture, and environmental sustainability challenges. Coupling the H2 derived from either water splitting or seawater splitting [120] with existing eNRR processes can reduce dependency on natural gas for H2 sources. For an efficient eNRR, the electrocatalyst plays a crucial role in driving the reduction reaction. Although there is ongoing research in this area to develop the best catalyst and process, the investigation remains plagued by a very low NH3 production rate, low FE, competing HER, limited nitrogen selectivity, and nitrogen activation. Researchers are exploring diverse catalysts to develop an efficient and environmentally sustainable method for NH3 production. To ensure the practicality, effectiveness, and repeatability of their investigations, it is imperative that these studies meticulously consider some key factors while formulating the catalyst. Firstly, DFT calculations should consider H, O, NH3, and NO x compound’s interactions with catalysts rather than just the interaction of N2, since molecules other than N2 could have more significant interaction with the catalyst surface, which hinders the N2 adsorption, it is imperative to consider the possible impurities that could be present in the system and their interference in the process of eNRR. Liu et al. have given a series of procedures for determining the eNRR activity of a catalyst considering the effect of impurities [121]. By comparing the adsorption energy, the catalyst most favourable for N2 adsorption over others must be reported and studied for mechanism [52]. Secondly, mechanistic DFT studies should be supplemented by experimental results to understand the relevance and feasibility of theoretical calculations in real experimental scenarios. Additionally, NH3 can also be produced by reducing nitrates, a ubiquitous pollutant in the environment; the volatile NH3 stands as a prevalent contaminant in gases. The concentration of NH3 fluctuates significantly from one location to another, contingent upon the surrounding agricultural activities, industrial processes, and levels of pollutants [122]; hence, the system must be free from nitrate species to confirm the N2 reduction. Caution must be taken while conducting eNRR since the area for false positives or errors is very high. Each component used in the system contributes towards error, and due to the very low production rate, small amounts of preexisting nitrogenous species would also account significantly. Every component, including catalyst purity, electrolyte, and gas purity, has to be scrutinised seriously before experiments. A flow chart for determining the eNRR activity of a catalyst was proposed by Liu et al. [123], which helps in the identification of false positives in the process by addressing the purity of the components and reproducibility of the experiment. A standard operating protocol has to be followed by researchers working on eNRR so that it would be easier to avoid false positives [52]. A cost-effective method for conformation of NH3 formation from N2 reduction is proposed, which eliminates the necessity of using isotope labelled N2 and considers the impurities which could be present in the experimental gas stream [66]. Electrocatalysts are being developed for eNRR to either inhibit competing reactions or enhance the adsorption and activation of nitrogen. However, for an electrocatalyst to perform optimally, combining these characteristics in a single catalyst is desired. By considering all these factors and understanding the underlying mechanism, an efficient and selective electrocatalyst can be designed for the electrochemical nitrogen reduction 6 Conclusions Ammonia, a zero-carbon energy carrier with a high energy density value, accounts for nearly 80% of the fertiliser industry, and the rest is mainly used for energy and pharmaceutical requirements. The conventional H-B process of NH3 synthesis is energy-intensive, a carbon accounting process, and non-sustainable. To overcome these drawbacks, electrochemical processes are being developed to make the synthesis carbon-free and sustainable in the future. The challenges include low N2 selectivity, competing HER, inefficient electrocatalyst, and low FE, which an efficient electrocatalyst can counter. To design a good catalyst, it is necessary to understand the reaction mechanism to overcome challenges in the process. Herein, the authors have reviewed the different reaction mechanisms in which nitrogen reduction reaction takes place on the electrocatalytic surface, which include dissociative, associative alternate, associative distal, associative enzymatic, Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction and surface hydrogenation mechanism. In the H-B process, the iron catalyst follows a dissociative mechanism that needs high energy, which explains the unpopularity of the mechanism in eNRR. The associative mechanism of nitrogen reduction is followed by most of the proposed catalysts, which were reported to give good results. In the MvK mechanism, the nitrogen atom of the catalyst itself undergoes a reaction and hence gives very good selectivity, but strictly for transition metal nitride catalysts. Lithium, being a perfect reducing agent (−3.05 V vs. SHE), easily forms lithium nitride (Li3N). Further, this lithium nitride gets converted to NH3 by reacting with protons available in the medium. The efficiency of the process is very good, and a significant amount of NH3 was reported. The surface hydrogenation mechanism is the most recently reported, that to be followed for noble metal catalysts at very low potential values. To understand all these mechanisms, first principle calculations using DFT are very useful in identifying the mechanism of the reaction corresponding to the catalyst used. The assumption for the mechanism followed by the electrocatalyst cannot be made based on the elements present in the catalyst, i.e., all the Fe or Fe-derived catalysts do not follow the same mechanism. The PDS (from DFT) is the most important factor in identifying the mechanism and optimum catalyst. Even though dissociative is the most challenging and energy-intensive mechanism, it is highly unpopular in eNRR. However, it must be addressed because employing the Ru catalyst will dominate the dissociative mechanism over other mechanisms. Many researchers have reported distal mechanism that it still suffers from low production rate and efficiency in some cases. The debate for the best mechanism is still a question, and further research could help identify the best mechanism and come up with solutions for addressing concerns related to eNRR. Based on our review, we assert that the MvK mechanism is the most favourable choice. This is due to the inherent capability of the catalyst’s selectivity toward dinitrogen and its ability to activate nitrogen. The eNRR process has come a long way. The contribution of different researchers in this field made the process feasible under ambient conditions by investigating various catalysts. By implementing available resources and gathered knowledge, we must make the process scalable and economical for energy applications. Sun, ACS Sustain. Chem. Eng. 6 (2018) 9545–9549. Abhishek Umesh Shetty obtained his Bachelor’s degree in Chemical Engineering from M. S. Ramaiah Institute of Technology, Bangalore in 2022. He worked as a Project Associate at M. S. Ramaiah Institute of Technology from 2022 to 2023. His research interests include catalysis, electrochemistry, and reaction engineering. Ravi Sankannavar completed his Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay in August 2019. He received his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in Chemical Engineering from R V College of Engineering, Bangalore (2009), and the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore (2011), respectively. Presently, Dr. Sankannavar is an Assistant Professor in the School of Chemical and Materials Science at the Indian Institute of Technology Goa. His research focuses on electrochemical energy conversion and storage processes, particularly water electrolysis, green ammonia synthesis, redox flow batteries, and the development of integrated electrochemical systems.

coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) holds significant promise as a sustainable alternative to the conventional large-scale Haber Bosch process, offering a carbon footprint-free approach for ammonia synthesis. While the process is thermodynamically feasible at ambient temperature and pressure, challenges such as the competing hydrogen evolution reaction, low nitrogen solubility in electrolytes, and the activation of inert dinitrogen (N2) gas adversely affect the performance of ammonia production. These hurdles result in low Faradaic efficiency and low ammonia production rate, which pose obstacles to the commercialisation of the process. Researchers have been actively designing and proposing various electrocatalysts to address these issues, but challenges still need to be resolved. A key strategy in electrocatalyst design lies in understanding the underlying mechanisms that govern the success or failure of the electrocatalyst in driving the electrochemical reaction. Through mechanistic studies, we gain valuable insights into the factors affecting the reaction, enabling us to propose optimised designs to overcome the barriers. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the various mechanisms involved in eNRR on the electrocatalyst surface. It delves into the various mechanisms such as dissociative, associative, Mars-van Krevelen, lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction and surface hydrogenation mechanisms of nitrogen reduction. By unravelling the intricacies of eNRR mechanisms and exploring promising avenues, we can pave the way for more efficient and commercially viable ammonia synthesis through this sustainable electrochemical process by designing an efficient electrocatalyst.
